description.narrative: Communities and community members in targeted communities in Sierra Leone. Sierra Leone Police teams , Local Policing Partnership Board, and Community based organization.

Cordaid promotes more effective, responsive and inclusive security and justice provision through its security and justice programmes. Cordaid has pioneered an innovative approach to tackling the aforementioned challenges through applying a results-based financing (RBF) model to security and justice provision. The approach is characterized by using the train & equip elements of standard security and justice sector reform incentives to focus on accountability and constructive relations between state duty-bearers and citizens. Informed by successful utilization of RBF in the health sector, Cordaid first introduced an RBF approach to security and justice (S&J) in 2011 in DR Congo. Subsequently, two projects were rolled-out: Restoring the Contract (2012-17) in Burundi and DRC, and CISPE (2017- ) in DRC. In the course of implementing these initiatives, Cordaid has refined the RBF for S&J model, adapting to the needs of beneficiaries and feedback from external evaluations and donors, evolving toward an “RBF 2.0” that is fit-for-purpose in the existing context. Adaptations integrated into the latest iteration of RBF for S&J include separation of quantitative and qualitative (i.e. process-oriented) indicators to clarify targets for beneficiaries, inclusion of lower-level governance actors and civil society organizations in RBF, and splitting the community verification process into an end-user verification and a broader community questionnaire (to reach people who did not use RBF-associated services). Most of these changes are related to better include local community representatives (women, youth, local business associations, etc.) in the RBF process and promote accountability. The proven success of Cordaid RBF for S&J programming in Burundi and DRC calls for adaptation and scaling-out of this approach globally. To do so, assessment is needed of how Cordaid interventions in DRC impact the local political economy, that is, power relations between local political actors, formal and informal, who have a central role in security and justice provision, and between citizens (especially women, youth and marginalized groups) and power-holders.
